channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: 3 dead, several wounded in cycle of South L.A. gang shootings, police say
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Single shooting in South L.A. is believed to have touched off vicious cycle of retaliation, officials say
item.content:encoded: Single shooting in South L.A. is believed to have touched off vicious cycle of retaliation, officials say

media:content.media:description: The Los Angeles Police Department's headquarters are shown in 2011. A man who complained he was struggling to breathe died in LAPD custody last month after officers ignored his repeated pleas for help, sources say.

item.title: LAPD officers named in fatal shooting of alleged gunman in South Central
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Officers Luke Coyle and Kevin Ruiz of the department's Newton Division fatally shot Daniel Hernandez during an April 30 pursuit.
item.content:encoded: Officers Luke Coyle and Kevin Ruiz of the department's Newton Division fatally shot Daniel Hernandez during an April 30 pursuit.

item.title: First youths test positive for coronavirus in L.A. County juvenile halls
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Two youths have tested positive for the novel coronavirus in L.A. County's juvenile halls. The teens were only recently booked and were kept away from the general population, officials say.
item.content:encoded: Two youths have tested positive for the novel coronavirus in L.A. County's juvenile halls. The teens were only recently booked and were kept away from the general population, officials say.

media:content.media:description: Los asaltos a guardias tanto en salas de menores como en campamentos aumentaron entre 2015 y 2018, pero disminuyeron ligeramente en el último año, según los datos publicados por el Departamento de Libertad Condicional. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Palm Desert man threw daughter off a cliff, stabbed good Samaritan trying to help, sheriff says
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A Palm Desert man crashed his car, stabbed a good Samaritan who tried to free his daughter from the wreck and flung the girl off a cliff, killing her, according to the Riverside County Sheriff's Department.
item.content:encoded: A Palm Desert man crashed his car, stabbed a good Samaritan who tried to free his daughter from the wreck and flung the girl off a cliff, killing her, according to the Riverside County Sheriff's Department.

item.title: First Californian to get coronavirus in community spread was infected at a nail salon, Newsom says
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: Newsom cited the case when asked why personal services, such as nail salons, must remain closed.
item.content:encoded: Newsom cited the case when asked why personal services, such as nail salons, must remain closed.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom speaks at a news conference in Sacramento on Feb. 26, 2020.

item.title: Masks will be required on L.A. Metro buses and trains starting Monday
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: The mask rule comes after Metro bus drivers said they were scared for their health and for the well-being of essential workers on board.
item.content:encoded: The mask rule comes after Metro bus drivers said they were scared for their health and for the well-being of essential workers on board.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- APRIL 02: Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority general service employee disinfects all high touch point areas such as handrails, elevator call buttons, and ticket vending machines at the Mariachi Plaza station in the Boyle Heights neighborhood on Thursday, April 2, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. Metro is doing everything possible to maintain a healthy and safe system for their customers during the coronavirus pandemic. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Protesters stage illegal rally at California Capitol to support law enforcement
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Protesters of California's stay-at-home orders returned for another unsanctioned rally Thursday, telling law enforcement officers they are forgiven for arresting them last week.
item.content:encoded: Protesters of California's stay-at-home orders returned for another unsanctioned rally Thursday, telling law enforcement officers they are forgiven for arresting them last week.

media:content.media:description: Pastor Tim Thompson of Riverside leads at protest against Gov. Gavin Newsom's restrictions aimed at stemming coronavirus at the California State Capitol in Sacramento on Thursday, May 7, 2020.

item.title: It's not too late to mark Teacher Appreciation Week. They could use it now more than ever
item.dc:creator: Faith E. Pinho
item.description: Teachers have adapted to the coronavirus outbreak and school shutdowns.
item.content:encoded: Teachers have adapted to the coronavirus outbreak and school shutdowns.

media:content.media:description: LYNWOOD, CA - APRIL 23, 2020: Patricia Cardenas, right, health technician at Hosler Middle School in Lynwood, CA, takes a computer to a waiting parent on Thursday, April 23, 2020. Remote digital learning has become a necessity during the coronavirus pandemic. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: San Francisco will allow certain businesses to reopen beginning May 18
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Phil Willon
item.description: San Francisco will allow certain businesses to reopen beginning May 18 as it eases its stay-at-home orders. But officials warn that they will keep track to make coronavirus infections don't spike.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco will allow certain businesses to reopen beginning May 18 as it eases its stay-at-home orders. But officials warn that they will keep track to make coronavirus infections don't spike.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO: The Golden State Warriors are in Oakland, but those in the know stay in S.F. Pictured: Evening commuters make their way across the Bay Bridge as a storm passes behind the San Francisco skyline as seen from Yerba Buena Island.

item.title: Here are the Orange County communities with coronavirus cases
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Orange County reported one additional coronavirus-linked fatality Thursday, bringing the region's total death toll to 66.
item.content:encoded: Orange County reported one additional coronavirus-linked fatality Thursday, bringing the region's total death toll to 66.

media:content.media:description: NEWPORT BEACH, CALIFORNIA MAY 2, 2020-People walk along Newport Beach even though a beach closure went into effect Saturday. California Governor Gavin Newsome's closed Orange County beaches to slow the spread of the coronavirus. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 138 employees at Central California meat plant test positive for coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Kings County Supervisor Doug Verboon said the outbreak at Central Valley Meat Company in Hanford accounts for nearly two-thirds of the coronavirus cases in the rural county, which has a total of 211 reported cases.
item.content:encoded: Kings County Supervisor Doug Verboon said the outbreak at Central Valley Meat Company in Hanford accounts for nearly two-thirds of the coronavirus cases in the rural county, which has a total of 211 reported cases.

media:content.media:description: Central Valley Meat in Hanford, Calif., was closed for a week in 2012 after animal rights group Compassion Over Killing submitted videos to the U.S. Department of Agriculture showing workers torturing cows with electric prods and spraying them with hot water.

item.title: Oversight panel to subpoena Sheriff Alex Villanueva for testimony on coronavirus in jails
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: The Sheriff Civilian Oversight Commission voted Thursday to subpoena L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva for testimony regarding the coronavirus outbreak in the jails.
item.content:encoded: The Sheriff Civilian Oversight Commission voted Thursday to subpoena L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva for testimony regarding the coronavirus outbreak in the jails.

media:content.media:description: Alex Villanueva, sheriff del Condado de Los Ángeles. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times).

item.title: California to reopen 25 DMV field offices on Friday after they were shut down amid coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California DMV will reopen 25 field offices after shutdown
item.content:encoded: California DMV will reopen 25 field offices after shutdown

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - AUGUST 07: A line of people wait to be helped at a California Department of Motor Vehicles Office stretches around the building at the South LA location on Tuesday, Aug. 7, 2018 in Los Angeles, Calif. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Hand sanitizer company is ordered to stop distribution over questionable claims
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The DOJ ordered an Orange County company to stop distributing hand-sanitizer products until it got FDA approval or removed certain claims from its labeling.
item.content:encoded: The DOJ ordered an Orange County company to stop distributing hand-sanitizer products until it got FDA approval or removed certain claims from its labeling.

media:content.media:description: An analysis of dozens of common chemicals that are considered safe in low doses suggests that some may increase cancer risk when combined. One of them was triclosan, an ingredient in some hand sanitizers.

item.title: Drive-through celebrations and car parades nixed in Santa Clara County
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The coronavirus outbreak has forced the cancellation of myriad life events. Santa Clara County won't even let you celebrate in your car now.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus outbreak has forced the cancellation of myriad life events. Santa Clara County won't even let you celebrate in your car now.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CALIFORNIA - MAY 5, 2020: Faculty and staff members cheer as seniors drive by after picking up their caps and gowns at Poly High School in the midst of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic on May 5, 2020 in Riverside, California. There won't be a graduation this year.(Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newsom unveils rules governing how quickly California communities can reopen businesses
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Taryn Luna
item.description: Newsom said earlier this week that bookstores, florists and others can reopen for curbside pickup Friday, unless barred by tougher local restrictions.
item.content:encoded: Newsom said earlier this week that bookstores, florists and others can reopen for curbside pickup Friday, unless barred by tougher local restrictions.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his plan for the gradual reopening of California businesses during a news conference at the Display California store in Sacramento, Calif., Tuesday, May 5, 2020. Newsom warned counties that going too far in loosening coronavirus restrictions, could endanger public health. Display California, which sells locally-made items from around the state, is planning to open for curbside service on Friday under upcoming state guidelines. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: Coronavirus torpedoes 50th L.A. Pride parade; online celebration planned
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: The L.A. Pride parade, which would have marked its 50th year, joins the list of events canceled or postponed because of the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. Pride parade, which would have marked its 50th year, joins the list of events canceled or postponed because of the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Revelers join the festivities for the 49th annual L.A. Pride parade in West Hollywood on Sunday.

item.title: California tops 2,500 coronavirus deaths as fears of second wave temper reopening efforts
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Anita Chabria
item.description: Los Angeles County, which continues to be the hardest hit area in California, announced 51 additional deaths linked to COVID-19 on Thursday.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County, which continues to be the hardest hit area in California, announced 51 additional deaths linked to COVID-19 on Thursday.

media:content.media:description: YUBA CITY, CA -- MAY 06: Andrew Wagner, a tattooer, of Olivehurst, applies an octopus design to the arm of Jordan Curiel, of Marysville, at Heart & Soul Tattoo on Wednesday, May 6, 2020, in Yuba City, CA. Every 30 minutes Wagner must stop and desensitize the table. The shop closes at 3 P.M. for an hour to sanitize the space. Sutter and Yuba counties, both north of Sacramento, are allowing businesses and restaurants to reopen, defying Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus pandemic. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Face masks will be an even bigger part of L.A. life as reopening begins
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Emily Alpert Reyes, Priscella Vega, Marisa Gerber
item.description: Here is where masks are currently required, as well as proposals that would dramatically increase face-covering requirements.
item.content:encoded: Here is where masks are currently required, as well as proposals that would dramatically increase face-covering requirements.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA - MAY 06, 2020 - - A masked pedestrian looks at the image of Taylor Swift while walking down a deserted Hollywood Blvd. on a hot afternoon in Hollywood on May 6, 2020. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus undercuts LAPD recruitment just as a decline in black officers looms
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: LAPD leaders are concerned about a looming decline in black officers, particularly as pandemic-related restrictions undercut recruitment efforts.
item.content:encoded: LAPD leaders are concerned about a looming decline in black officers, particularly as pandemic-related restrictions undercut recruitment efforts.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA JANUARY 7, 2015 -- An LAPD cruiser sits parked at Hollywood and Highland near the scene of a shooting early Wednesday, January 7, 2015, in which authorities said a man stood on a sidewalk and began randomly firing into the air. The incident occurred about 2 a.m. on Hollywood Boulevard off Cosmo Street, said Sgt. Chad Lewis of the LAPD's Hollywood division. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Brush fire erupts in exclusive Hollister Ranch amid strong winds and sweltering temperatures
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry

item.content:encoded: The fire broke out shortly after 2 a.m. in medium brush between Gaviota State Beach and the Hollister Ranch guard gate.

media:content.media:description: A firefighter battles a brush fire that broke out in the Hollister Ranch area of Santa Barbara County early Thursday.
media:content.media:credit: Daniel Bertucelli/Santa Barbara County Fire Department

item.title: California reopening begins Friday: Here is what it is going to look like
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Marisa Gerber, Maura Dolan, Priscella Vega, Gary Warth
item.description: Across Southern California and in the Bay Area, communities are preparing to allow retailers to reopen, with restrictions.
item.content:encoded: Across Southern California and in the Bay Area, communities are preparing to allow retailers to reopen, with restrictions.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MAY 6, 2020: Jaime Miranda creates an arrangement at Lupita's Flowers in downtown Los Angeles on Wednesday, May 6, 2020. Flower wholesalers are allowed to reopen during the coronavirus pandemic in downtown Los Angeles ahead of Mother's Day weekend. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Pool rules: Riverside County says spread out, stay in your lane

item.description: Pool parties are frowned on, as health officials offer guidelines for the use of apartment and HOA pools and spas.
item.content:encoded: Pool parties are frowned on, as health officials offer guidelines for the use of apartment and HOA pools and spas.

item.title: Coronavirus plunges California into worst budget deficit in state history

item.description: California's state government faces a $54-billion budget deficit through next summer, according to an analysis released Thursday.
item.content:encoded: California's state government faces a $54-billion budget deficit through next summer, according to an analysis released Thursday.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA MAY 6, 2020-Monique Hernandez, a registered nurse for Riverside Community Hospital, attends a candlelight vigil for nurse Celia Marcos outside Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center in Los Angeles Wednesday. Marco died from the coronavirus. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: We need to prepare for the mental health impact of coronavirus on kids
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli
item.description: More children are likely to experience toxic stress during the pandemic, which could lead to devastating impacts in the future.
item.content:encoded: More children are likely to experience toxic stress during the pandemic, which could lead to devastating impacts in the future.

item.title: Broken gel nails. Gnarly roots. Coronavirus disrupts L.A. beauty and wellness industry
item.dc:creator: Gale Holland
item.description: Home color kits and Zoom crystal readings fill the void. But underground services break the lockdown.
item.content:encoded: Home color kits and Zoom crystal readings fill the void. But underground services break the lockdown.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - APR. 17, 2020. Andi Scarbrough owns a Santa Monica salon called Crown Works where she melds spiritual practices and rituals with basic hair services. The coronavirus pandemic has grounded her at her Topanga Canyon home, from which she is doing virtual consultations, blogging and some online presentations for her followers. . (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 2 counties defied Newsom and reopened. Now California warns restaurants could lose licenses if opened too early
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: California says bars that reopen without state permission could lose alcohol license
item.content:encoded: California says bars that reopen without state permission could lose alcohol license

media:content.media:description: MARYSVILLE, CA -- MAY 05: Anthony Frank, center, with wife Melia Campbell, of Plumas Lake, enjoy their first night out in weeks at Silver Dollar Saloon on Tuesday, May 5, 2020, in Marysville, CA. Silver Dollar Saloon has been closed to diners, only offering take-out and delivery, since March 18th. Owner Joe Ferrie had laid off 23 employees. Sutter and Yuba counties, both north of Sacramento, are allowing businesses and restaurants to reopen, defying Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus pandemic. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Los Angeles' mayor allows wholesale dealers to start selling under strict social distancing guidelines.

Flower wholesalers are allowed to reopen during the coronavirus pandemic in downtown Los Angeles ahead of Mother's Day weekend. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Skip the steak, buy the brisket: Consumers need to be flexible amid beef bottlenecks
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Where's the beef? In California, it is still available, but meat eaters might need to settle for cuts other than prime steaks. The industry is dealing with production backups caused by coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Where's the beef? In California, it is still available, but meat eaters might need to settle for cuts other than prime steaks. The industry is dealing with production backups caused by coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: California's livestock industry is urging consumers to try out cuts of beef other than prime steaks, like these seen in a Jan. 18, 2010 file photo. The coronavirus pandemic has created bottlenecks in processing plants, so meat eaters might need to get their fix with unusual cuts.

item.title: Desperate for coronavirus help, California spending billions on no-bid contracts with little accountability
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez, Adam Elmahrek, Ben Poston, Kim Christensen
item.description: Desperate for coronavirus help, California spending billions on no-bid coronavirus contracts, little accountability
item.content:encoded: Desperate for coronavirus help, California spending billions on no-bid coronavirus contracts, little accountability

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this April 10, 2020, file photo, wearing protective masks ground crew at the Los Angeles International airport unload supplies of medical personal protective equipment from a China Southern Cargo plane. Three million surgical masks arrived in California last weekend as the first shipment in a major deal cut by California Gov. Gavin Newsom for 200 million masks per month to protect health care and other workers from the coronavirus.. (AP Photo/Richard Vogel, File)

item.title: Banks: Pain, fear and isolation. COVID-19 made his hospital stay even more surreal and sad
item.dc:creator: Sandy Banks
item.description: The public has been warned to avoid emergency rooms because of coronavirus cases. But staying home undoubtedly made my son-in-law's condition worse.
item.content:encoded: The public has been warned to avoid emergency rooms because of coronavirus cases. But staying home undoubtedly made my son-in-law's condition worse.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA-MARCH 18, 2020-At UCLA Medical Center, an elderly man leaves the emergency room with a mask on outside the temporary testing area. Testing for Covid-19 is going on at UCLA Medical Center. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Don't go visit your mom' on Mother's Day, San Francisco health director advises
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: The director of the San Francisco Department of Public Health told residents Wednesday not to visit their mothers on Mother's Day, even if wearing masks and keeping six feet apart.
item.content:encoded: The director of the San Francisco Department of Public Health told residents Wednesday not to visit their mothers on Mother's Day, even if wearing masks and keeping six feet apart.

media:content.media:description: Evelyn Linares sells flowers at the Los Angeles Flower Market Wednesday, May 6, 2020, in Los Angeles. Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti on Tuesday said he would allow wholesale florists to open as a horticultural exemption for the upcoming Mother's Day.

item.title: L.A. County and the Bay Area take a conservative approach as California eases stay-at-home rules

item.description: With parts of the California economy poised to reopen Friday, cities will be taking it slow over concerns that COVID-19 remains a significant threat.
item.content:encoded: With parts of the California economy poised to reopen Friday, cities will be taking it slow over concerns that COVID-19 remains a significant threat.

media:content.media:description: MARYSVILLE, CA -- MAY 05: Anthony Frank, center, with wife Melia Campbell, of Plumas Lake, enjoy their first night out in weeks at Silver Dollar Saloon on Tuesday, May 5, 2020, in Marysville, CA. Silver Dollar Saloon has been closed to diners, only offering take-out and delivery, since March 18th. Owner Joe Ferrie had laid off 23 employees. Sutter and Yuba counties, both north of Sacramento, are allowing businesses and restaurants to reopen, defying Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus pandemic. item.title: Letters to the Editor: Does Trump think he can just bluff the coronavirus?
item.description: Trump might shut down the coronavirus task force. This won't do anything to boost our response to the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Trump might shut down the coronavirus task force. This won't do anything to boost our response to the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump participates in a tour of a Honeywell International plant that manufactures personal protective equipment, Tuesday, May 5, 2020, in Phoenix. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci)

item.title: Skelton: Newsom is relying on public health officials for his coronavirus response. But he has to listen to others too
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: In the U.S. no one rules absolutely — not even public health officials fighting the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: In the U.S. no one rules absolutely — not even public health officials fighting the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday April 14, 2020 file photo,, California Gov. Gavin Newsom speaks during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. Newsom announced Friday, April 24 that taxpayers will pay restaurants to make meals for millions of California's seniors during the coronavirus pandemic, an initiative that could pump billions of dollars into a devastated industry. California governments scrambled to set up programs to have three meals delivered to seniors each day amid the coronavirus crisis, but it wasn't clear when deliveries would start going out the door. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli,File)

item.title: After this week's near-record heat, California will return to cooler weather in mid-May
item.dc:creator: Paul Duginski
item.description: A trough off the West Coast is expected to bring a robust cooling trend to California next week.
item.content:encoded: A trough off the West Coast is expected to bring a robust cooling trend to California next week.

media:content.media:description: Temperatures are likely to be below normal in much of California during the period.

item.description: Two people were killed and another two were wounded Wednesday in four shootings in South Los Angeles, law enforcement authorities said.
item.content:encoded: Two people were killed and another two were wounded Wednesday in four shootings in South Los Angeles, law enforcement authorities said.

item.title: LAPD officer in violent beating video has been involved in three prior shootings
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, James Queally
item.description: Officer Frank Hernandez has been involved in at least three on-duty shootings, including one where the city's Police Commission found fault with his actions.
item.content:encoded: Officer Frank Hernandez has been involved in at least three on-duty shootings, including one where the city's Police Commission found fault with his actions.

media:content.media:description: An LAPD recruit officer class marches in for inspection during graduation exercises in the plaza of the downtown LAPD headquarters building. An audit has found no reliable way to track an extended-injury leave program, which costs the city millions of dollars.
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Chinese firm will reimburse $247.5 million in controversial mask deal, contract shows
item.dc:creator: John Myers, Melody Gutierrez, Adam Elmahrek
item.description: Just two days after refusing to make the contract public, Gov. Gavin Newsom's administration disclosed the 42-page document on its nearly $1-billion coronavirus mask deal with Chinese electric car maker BYD.
item.content:encoded: Just two days after refusing to make the contract public, Gov. Gavin Newsom's administration disclosed the 42-page document on its nearly $1-billion coronavirus mask deal with Chinese electric car maker BYD.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday, April 14, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. On a near daily basis since outlining his criteria for someday easing stay-at-home orders, Newsom, who recently allowed scheduled surgeries to resume, has warned Californians that, while he understands their desires to get back to work and a sense of normalcy, lifting the orders too soon could be a public health mistake. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

item.title: Bay Area, citing rising coronavirus cases, to keep stay-at-home order even as Newsom eases rules

item.content:encoded: "The numbers are still going up," San Francisco Mayor London Breed said, emphasizing that Bay Area health officers can continue to enforce tighter restrictions.

(Photo by Josh Edelson / AFP) (Photo by JOSH EDELSON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Orange County's beaches are reopening following coronavirus closures. Here are their hours

item.description: Many Orange County beaches have reopened following Gov. Gavin Newsom's brief "hard closure," but their hours vary.
item.content:encoded: Many Orange County beaches have reopened following Gov. Gavin Newsom's brief "hard closure," but their hours vary.

media:content.media:description: NEWPORT BEACH, CA -- MONDAY, MAY 4, 2020: An aerial view of a few surfers and beach-goers enjoying a nice day at the beach despite Gov. Gavin Newsom's hard closure, which is still in place in Newport Beach, CA, on May 4, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Orange County tops 3,000 coronavirus cases as death toll reaches 65
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Despite the recent fatalities, the county's observed mortality rate associated with COVID-19 remained at about 2.1% — still significantly lower than the state's, which is roughly 4%.
item.content:encoded: Despite the recent fatalities, the county's observed mortality rate associated with COVID-19 remained at about 2.1% — still significantly lower than the state's, which is roughly 4%.

media:content.media:description: LAGUNA BEACH, CA - MAY 05: David Peck, 82, said "I want to cry. It's wonderful" while enjoying the view of Laguna Beach on Tuesday morning as city with State's blessings reopened its beaches for active use only. The first phase of the reopening includes 6-10 a.m. hours Mondays through Fridays. in Laguna Beach on Tuesday, May 5, 2020 in Laguna Beach, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. weighs requiring masks when people leave their homes

California Governor Gavin Newsome's closed Orange County beaches to slow the spread of the coronavirus. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Whale that washed ashore in Ventura County towed out to sea
item.dc:creator: Melissa Gomez
item.description: The animal's cause of death was inconclusive because a full examination was hampered by stay-at-home and social distancing orders issued amid the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: The animal's cause of death was inconclusive because a full examination was hampered by stay-at-home and social distancing orders issued amid the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: Ashley Bautista, the Ventura County spokesperson, was on a walk with her sons on Sunday when she spotted a gray whale carcass at Emma Wood State Beach. It was towed out to sea on Tuesday morning, May 5, 2020, after researchers did a brief investigation into its cause of death.

item.content:encoded: The order streamlines workers' compensation claims and establishes that any essential worker infected with COVID-19 contracted the virus on the job.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses the weekend shooting at the Poway Chabad Synagogue north of San Diego during a news conference Monday, April 29, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom said he would increase spending to pay for increasing security at nonprofit organizations at higher risk because of their ideology, beliefs or mission. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Newport Beach reopens shoreline as California continues unlocking Orange County coast

Gavin Newsom's hard closure, which is still in place in Newport Beach, CA, on May 4, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom is allowing couples to wed through videoconferencing during the coronavirus pandemic, but L.A. County has no system in place for it.

media:content.media:description: ANAHEIM-CA-APRIL 23, 2020: Russel and Kathleen Sion of Torrance, both 29, from left, celebrate tying the knot in a parking lot at the Honda Center in Anaheim on Thursday, April 23, 2020. The County of Orange Clerk Recorder is performing wedding ceremonies at the Honda Center in Anaheim. Employees implemented a variety of social distancing techniques to safely issue licenses and marry couples during the novel coronavirus pandemic. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Drive-throughs and drive-ins were fading. Coronavirus made them a lifeline
item.dc:creator: Carolina A. Miranda
item.description: The drive-through is derided; the drive-in, nearly extinct. But the coronavirus outbreak has made them essential for food, tests, a movie and church.
item.content:encoded: The drive-through is derided; the drive-in, nearly extinct. But the coronavirus outbreak has made them essential for food, tests, a movie and church.

media:content.media:description: MONTCLAIR, CA - APRIL 30: A scene from "Knives Out," with actor Don Johnson, seen at the Mission Tiki Drive-in Theatre, in Montclair, CA, photographed Thursday, April 30, 2020, during the coronavirus pandemic. Originally opened with onea screen in 1956, the Mission Tiki expanded to four screens in 1975 and began renovation in 2006, updating to FM transmitters and digital projectors and repaved the property. The Mission Tiki has also been hosting a swap meet on weekends since the 60s, but with the coronavirus pandemic, has had to temporarily close. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Latinos test positive for coronavirus at overwhelming levels in San Francisco survey
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Latinos accounted for more than 99% of positive COVID-19 cases among those tested in the city's Mission District.
item.content:encoded: Latinos accounted for more than 99% of positive COVID-19 cases among those tested in the city's Mission District.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO, CA - APRIL 25: A Mission District resident (no name given) is checked in and screened while in line as volunteers and staff with UCSF work to move people through a Coronavirus testing site for Mission district residents at Cesar Chavez Elementary School in San Francisco, Calif. Saturday, April 25, 2020. UCSF is providing free testing for Coronavirus and its antibodies to members of the Latino community at four locations across the city starting Saturday. In the United States, the virus has proven to be particularly virulent for the Latino and African American communities. (Jessica Christian/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images)
media:content.media:credit: San Francisco Chronicle/Hearst N/Hearst Newspapers via Getty Imag

item.title: Students accused of sexual misconduct get stronger protections under new federal rules
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: Students accused of sexual misconduct gain stronger protections under controversial new Title IX rules announced by Education Secretary Betsy DeVos.
item.content:encoded: Students accused of sexual misconduct gain stronger protections under controversial new Title IX rules announced by Education Secretary Betsy DeVos.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Feb. 27, 2020, file photo, Education Secretary Betsy DeVos pauses as she testifies during a hearing of a House Appropriations Sub-Committee on the fiscal year 2021 budget on Capitol Hill in Washington. The Trump administration is barring most international students and all students who entered the U.S. illegally from receiving emergency college grants approved by Congress as part of a $2.2 trillion coronavirus rescue package. DeVos issued the restriction in new guidelines released Tuesday, April 21, 2020, telling colleges how to distribute more than $6 billion in grants meant to help students cover unexpected costs triggered by the pandemic. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon, File)

item.title: Reopening L.A. will be slow as coronavirus cases and deaths keep mounting
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Alene Tchekmedyian, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: It's unclear how quickly L.A. will reopen. But it will likely be slower than other areas.
item.content:encoded: It's unclear how quickly L.A. will reopen. But it will likely be slower than other areas.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 05: The streets are quiet with closed signs in Little Tokyo Tuesday morning as Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti said Monday that different cities will need to take different steps to emerge from the coronavirus Covid-19 pandemic - induced shutdown and that city and county officials are still trying to determine the safest course. The city's "Safer At Home" order is in effect until May 15, and Garrett said he hoped steps restricting commerce could begin to be rolled back by then. Downtown on Tuesday, May 5, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: With devastating speed, coronavirus spread through a Long Beach fire station. But these firefighters battled back

item.content:encoded: In rapid succession, firefighters in one Long Beach station got COVID-19. The city scrambled to stop the spread and enacted changes.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CALIF. - APR. 15, 2020. Firefighters respond to a call at Long Beach Fire Station 11 on Wednesday, Apr. 15, 2020. Eight firefighters at the station were tested for COVID-19. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Will reopening California bring more coronavirus cases, deaths?
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Iris Lee, Phil Willon, Hannah Fry

item.title: Judge who ordered ICE to immediately release California immigrants overruled; detainees will stay put

item.content:encoded: A panel of three 9th Circuit Court of Appeals judges sided with the Trump administration over the release of detainees from the Adelanto ICE Processing Facility.

item.title: Photos taken at Kobe Bryant crash site should be against the law, California lawmaker says
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Outraged that deputies allegedly shared photos from the site of a helicopter crash that killed Kobe Bryant, his daughter and seven others, a California lawmaker wants to make it a crime for law enforcement officers to take unauthorized photographs of those killed in fatal accidents or at crime scenes.

item.description: A lawsuit announced Tuesday seeks refunds for students who, as a result of the coronavirus closures, lost out on in-person instruction, housing, meals and other elements of campus life and were not paid back tuition and fees.

item.content:encoded: Lifting coronavirus stay-at-home restrictions too soon will lead to more infections and deaths and be bad for the economy, officials in Northern California say.

media:content.media:description: MARYSVILLE, CA -- MAY 05: Jeremiah Pino, left, Lydia Perez, of Marysville, with server Aimee Roux, right, enjoy their first night out in weeks at Silver Dollar Saloon on Tuesday, May 5, 2020, in Marysville, CA. "This is nice, enjoying the evening out with friends," said Perez. Silver Dollar Saloon has been closed to diners, only offering take-out and delivery, since March 18th. Owner Joe Ferrie had laid off 23 employees. Sutter and Yuba counties, both north of Sacramento, are allowing businesses and restaurants to reopen, defying Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus pandemic. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California Highway Patrol officers fatally shoot motorist on 60 Freeway

item.title: Orange County reports four new coronavirus deaths amid rise in hospitalized patients

item.content:encoded: Orange County health officials Tuesday reported four additional coronavirus-linked fatalities, as the number of people hospitalized with COVID-19 countywide surpassed 200 for the second time in less than a week.

media:content.media:description: LAGUNA BEACH, CALIF. - MAY 2, 2020. Cops and protesters find a shady spot along Pacific Coast Highway in Laguna Beach on Saturday, May 2, 2020. California Gov. Gavin Newson ordered a hard closure of Orange County beaches this weekend. But responding to public pressure in recent days, Newson has implied that a gradual reopening of beaches, parks and the economy following the coronavirus lockdown could begin as early as next week. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ventura County moves toward a phased reopening of some businesses by week's end
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: Businesses such as bookstores, clothing stores, florists and sporting goods stores will be available to open up shop for curbside pickup. Associated manufacturers and supply chains for these retail stores will also be allowed to open.
item.content:encoded: Businesses such as bookstores, clothing stores, florists and sporting goods stores will be available to open up shop for curbside pickup. Associated manufacturers and supply chains for these retail stores will also be allowed to open.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA -- APRIL 25: Visitors practice social distancing at the beach on Saturday, April 25, 2020, in Ventura, CA. Los Angeles County's beaches along its 72 mile coast remain closed this weekend due to the coronavirus. But beaches in neighboring Ventura and Orange County are open. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

The incident occurred about 2 a.m. on Hollywood Boulevard off Cosmo Street, said Sgt. Chad Lewis of the LAPD's Hollywood division. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California DMV offices could reopen this month, but with coronavirus changes

item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County reported 58 new COVID-19 related deaths, bringing the total to more than 1,300. Roughly 1,638 new cases were confirmed.

(Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California sues Uber and Lyft, saying drivers are employees
item.dc:creator: Suhauna Hussain, Johana Bhuiyan
item.description: California's suit against Uber and Lyft says the companies have illegally treated drivers as independent contractors, depriving them of benefits.
item.content:encoded: California's suit against Uber and Lyft says the companies have illegally treated drivers as independent contractors, depriving them of benefits.

media:content.media:description: California Atty. Gen. Xavier Becerra said the state has joined others as a plaintiff in a lawsuit challenging the Trump administration's latest travel ban.

item.title: 6th Terminal Island prisoner dies of COVID-19; congresswoman says Fauci 'a little alarmed'
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: A sixth inmate at the Terminal Island federal prison in Los Angeles died over the weekend after testing positive for the coronavirus infection.
item.content:encoded: A sixth inmate at the Terminal Island federal prison in Los Angeles died over the weekend after testing positive for the coronavirus infection.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO CA. APRIL 29, 2020 -- Exterior view of the Federal Correctional Institution Terminal Island in San Pedro. Nearly half of the inmates at the federal prison at Terminal Island in San Pedro have tested positive for the coronavirus in what had has become the nation's worst outbreak in a federal penitentiary. As of Tuesday, 443 of the prison's 1,055 inmates have the virus, along with 10 staff members. Two inmates have already died of complications related to COVID-19, according to the Bureau of Prisons. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California sees first drop in weekly coronavirus deaths. Is it a turning point?
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Iris Lee
item.description: A Los Angeles Times data analysis found the weekly death toll fell nearly 9% for the seven-day period that ended Sunday.
item.content:encoded: A Los Angeles Times data analysis found the weekly death toll fell nearly 9% for the seven-day period that ended Sunday.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA-MAY 1, 2020: Lee Bloom, 39, of Los Angeles and his son Evan, 7 wear protective masks against the coronavirus during a visit to Kenneth Hahn State Recreation Area in Los Angeles. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ventura County Fair becomes the latest summer event canceled due to coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The pandemic has forced officials throughout the state to ax large-scale events, including the San Diego County Fair, Orange County Fair and California State Fair.
item.content:encoded: The pandemic has forced officials throughout the state to ax large-scale events, including the San Diego County Fair, Orange County Fair and California State Fair.

media:content.media:description: Ho, Lawrence K.   VENTURA, CA. AUG. 11, 2010. A crowd favorite, the All Alaskan Racing Pigs. Ventura County Fair at the Ventura Fairgrounds in Ventura on Aug. 11, 2010. (Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Historic Troubadour nightclub launches GoFundMe page, calls survival 'a big if'
item.dc:creator: Randall Roberts
item.description: The general manager of the Troubadour, which famously launched Elton John's career, says 'to survive, we're going to need all the help we can get.'
item.content:encoded: The general manager of the Troubadour, which famously launched Elton John's career, says 'to survive, we're going to need all the help we can get.'

media:content.media:description: A guard stands outside the Troubadour where Guns N' Roses will perform tonight.

item.title: Big cities like L.A. might be slower to reopen than suburbs and smaller communities
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Taryn Luna, James Queally, Kailyn Brown, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Officials in Los Angeles and the Bay Area have been more cautious, saying they fear reopening too early could cause further coronavirus outbreaks.
item.content:encoded: Officials in Los Angeles and the Bay Area have been more cautious, saying they fear reopening too early could cause further coronavirus outbreaks.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 04: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced select retail businesses will be allowed to reopen starting Friday in California during the coronavirus pandemic on Monday, May 4, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Motorist fatally shot by CHP during traffic stop on 60 Freeway in Monterey Park
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: Video from the scene of a fatal shooting by the CHP of a motorist on the 60 Freeway appears to show a sheathed sword lying in the roadway.
item.content:encoded: Video from the scene of a fatal shooting by the CHP of a motorist on the 60 Freeway appears to show a sheathed sword lying in the roadway.

media:content.media:description: CHP officers at the scene on a fatal officer-involved shooting, Monday evening, May 4, 2020.

item.title: Voices from the spectrum: Autistic people deal with the coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Autistic people have diverse experiences that resist easy generalization. But in recent interviews, a number of autistic adults say that many are practiced in dealing with the challenges.
item.content:encoded: Autistic people have diverse experiences that resist easy generalization. But in recent interviews, a number of autistic adults say that many are practiced in dealing with the challenges.

media:content.media:description: CHATSWORTH, CA - APRIL 28: Hector Ramirez poses for a portrait outside his home on Tuesday, April 28, 2020 in Chatsworth, CA. Ramirez is autistic, and COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted his daily routine. He says that he has been using coping mechanisms to help him deal with his isolation. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Rotting food. Hungry masses. Chaotic supply chains. Coronavirus upends the U.S. food system
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: During the coronavirus crisis, food producers, distributors and retailers in California, producer of much of the U.S. food supply, scramble to adapt.
item.content:encoded: During the coronavirus crisis, food producers, distributors and retailers in California, producer of much of the U.S. food supply, scramble to adapt.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA -- APRIL 28: Associates fill orders for both Ralphs and Food 4 Less grocery stores at the Ralphs Distribution Center on Tuesday, April 28, 2020, in Riverside, CA. The 80 acre, 1.2 million square feet, full service distribution center employing 1100 workers took on more product after automated warehouses couldn't keep up with the spike in demand after restaurants were shuttered. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Scientists say a now-dominant strain of the coronavirus could be more contagious than original
item.dc:creator: Ralph Vartabedian
item.description: A mutation in the novel coronavirus has led to a new strain viewed as more contagious than the virus that emerged from China, according to a new study.
item.content:encoded: A mutation in the novel coronavirus has led to a new strain viewed as more contagious than the virus that emerged from China, according to a new study.

media:content.media:description: This undated electron microscope image from the U.S. National Institutes of Health in February shows the Novel Coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, the virus causes COVID-19. Scientists say this original version of the coronavirus has mutated and become more infectious.

item.title: Garcetti says L.A. might not begin reopening by Friday, vows 'careful consideration'
item.dc:creator: James Queally, Colleen Shalby, Taryn Luna
item.description: The city's 'Safer At Home' order is in effect until May 15, and Garcetti said he hoped steps restricting commerce could begin to be rolled back by then.
item.content:encoded: The city's 'Safer At Home' order is in effect until May 15, and Garcetti said he hoped steps restricting commerce could begin to be rolled back by then.

item.title: Beverly Hills loosens restrictions on medical procedures, including plastic surgery, in coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: The Beverly Hills City Council voted 4 to 1 last week to join the state in easing restrictions on elective surgeries.
item.content:encoded: The Beverly Hills City Council voted 4 to 1 last week to join the state in easing restrictions on elective surgeries.

media:content.media:description: A view of virtually empty Rodeo Drive on Wednesday.
